articles.title: FEBRUARY 1989
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) event schedule for February and March 1989. It details various activities including star parties at Fremont Peak and Henry Coe State Park, general meetings featuring guest speakers on topics like 'The Very Large Array' and the history of astronomy textbooks, board meetings, and an introductory observational astronomy class.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces the upcoming election for five members to the Board of Directors at the February meeting. Current members Tom Ahl, Steve Greenberg, Paul Mancuso, Duncan Munro, and Jim Van Nuland are all standing for re-election, with additional nominees to be accepted. Other directors whose terms continue for another year include Gene Cisneros, Connie Fleenor, Jack Peterson, and Brian Zehring.

articles.title: OOPS!!! INTRODUCTORY ASTRONOMY CLASS RESUMES JANUARY 21ST!!!
articles.summary: Jack Pielack's Introductory Astronomy Class resumed on January 21st, correcting an earlier erroneous date of February 18th. The class is open to all interested in learning about the night sky, covering topics such as constellations, telescope use, astrophotography, and deep-sky observing, and will run for ten months. The author also suggests the SJAA Board fund the use of the West Valley College planetarium for class dates.

articles.title: INSTALLATION OF OFFICERS
articles.summary: The article announces a procedural change regarding the installation of new officers. To address confusion caused by a long delay between February elections and July installations, the Board has decided to move the installation ceremony to the March General Meeting. This adjustment, which does not require By-Law changes, aims to reduce the 'lame duck' period for officers not re-elected and clarify voting rights.

articles.title: FEBRUARY STARRY NIGHTS BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: The article provides an astronomical guide for February, highlighting observing opportunities and challenges. It covers the minor Delta Leonids meteor shower, various Galilean satellite events around Jupiter, and a deep-sky challenge featuring Barnard's Loop (Sh2-276) in Orion. Additionally, it announces a total lunar eclipse occurring on February 20th, with specific timing for the west coast.

articles.title: BY SHERRILL HUTCHISON
articles.summary: This article provides observational astronomy insights, beginning with tips for observing and photographing a lunar shadow event. It details a 1988 fireball sighting in Oregon, noting its visual characteristics, sounds, and an attempt at specimen recovery. The piece concludes with a discussion from an SJAA meeting, where the Mars Project presented arguments for and against the artificial nature of the 'Face on Mars' in the Cydonia region, emphasizing the need for further research and better photographic evidence.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: ASTRO ADS provides a free advertising service for non-commercial entities to sell astronomically related products or services. Submissions should be sent to Editor John P. Gleason by the 15th of each month, with ads running for approximately three months. This service facilitates a marketplace for the astronomy community.

articles.title: CELESTRON SUPER POLARIS MOUNT
articles.summary: This document comprises a collection of classified advertisements primarily for used astronomical equipment, including various telescopes, mounts, eyepieces, and accessories. Items for sale range from Celestron Super Polaris mounts and C8OF fluorite refractors to Meade Newtonian reflectors and complete telescope packages. The listings also include a 'wanted' section for specific telescope models and back issues of Telescope Making magazine.

articles.title: THE GREAT RED SPOT OF JUPITER
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland reports unusual, sudden longitudinal jumps of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), up to 5 degrees, an atypical movement for a short period. He observed changes in the surrounding belt material and the Red Spot Hollow's position, theorizing these shifts might be caused by an unseen nearby feature, as has occurred historically. The article concludes by providing observing tips for when the GRS is centrally visible from Earth, encouraging others to report any relevant sightings.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PST
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed schedule of dates and times, in Pacific Standard Time (PST), when Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) will transit the meridian. The listed times span from late January through mid-March, offering convenient viewing opportunities for observers. This information is highly valuable for astronomers planning to observe or image this prominent planetary feature.

articles.title: DISCOVERY LAUNCH DATE SLIPS TO FEBRUARY 23RD
articles.summary: The launch date for the Space Shuttle Discovery has been delayed by five days, now scheduled for February 23rd. This slip is attributed to minor processing delays. Discovery's main payload for this mission is a TDRS data relay satellite.

articles.title: NEW COMMERCIAL LAUNCH SCHEDULE FOR 1989
articles.summary: This article outlines the commercial launch schedule for expendable boosters in 1989, complementing a previously released shuttle schedule. It details various communication, military, and scientific satellites from India, Britain, Japan, and international organizations like Intelsat and Inmarsat. Additionally, it mentions unannounced U.S. Department of Defense launches, including Navstar GPS satellites on Delta-2 flights and the first Titan-4 launch.

articles.title: CHINA TO LAUNCH INTERNATIONAL COMMUNICATION SATELLITES
articles.summary: China has reached an agreement to launch up to nine U.S. and international communication satellites using its Long March Boosters through 1994. As part of this deal, China has committed to not subsidize its launch services excessively, aiming to avoid undercutting the U.S. commercial launch industry.

articles.title: SOVIETS RETURN AFTER 1 YEAR IN SPACE
articles.summary: Two Soviet cosmonauts, Titov and Manarov, along with French cosmonaut Chretieu, returned to Earth on December 21, 1988, after Titov and Manarov completed a full year aboard the MIR space station. This significant long-duration mission is considered a crucial step towards future human exploration, including missions to Mars. A new crew is currently on MIR and is expected to remain until spring.

articles.title: COSMONAUT ASSAULTS FRENCH EXPERIMENT ON MIR SPACE STATION
articles.summary: Cosmonaut Volkov successfully freed a stuck French experiment on the Mir space station during a 6-hour spacewalk on December 9, 1988. He resolved the issue by repeatedly kicking the structure with his boot while the station was out of radio contact with ground controllers.

articles.title: BY: PATRICK DONNELLY
articles.summary: The author recounts a successful stargazing session on December 26, 1988, observing numerous double and triple stars in the constellation Aries with a telescope. Despite impending clouds and moonlight, fourteen systems were identified and described, including detailed notes on their magnitudes, separations, and positions. The article highlights several notable examples like Pi-Arietis, Gamma Arietis, and Epsilon-Arietis, providing practical tips for observers.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Four new comets have been discovered recently, with three found by amateur astronomers, though preliminary orbits suggest they are unlikely to brighten significantly. Comet activity in general remains low. One notable discovery was Comet SSM 6 (1988p) by the Solar Max Satellite, a fainter sungrazer that disappeared into a streamer.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article details the discovery of four comets in late 1988 and early 1989: Comet Yanaka (1988r), Comet Yanaka (1989a), Comet Helin-Roman-Crockett (1989b), and Comet Bradfield (1989c). For each comet, it provides information on the discoverer(s), discovery method, approximate magnitude, celestial location, and general orbital characteristics such as proximity to the sun and expected brightness changes.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article discusses why comets are more frequently discovered in the morning sky, a phenomenon supported by Dr. Everhart's work and the author's extensive personal experience. The author dedicates most comet hunting efforts to after midnight due to favorable observing conditions such as reduced airglow, settled atmospheric particles, less manmade light pollution, and improved observer alertness and dark adaptation. Despite these advantages, challenges like sleepiness and dewing of optics can arise during morning observations.

articles.title: OFFICERS
articles.summary: This document lists the officers of an organization, detailing their positions, names, and contact phone numbers. The listed positions include President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer, and Editor, along with their respective officeholders and phone extensions.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing different membership options and their costs, including 'Membership only', 'Membership/S&T', and 'Junior'. It provides instructions for submitting the form and payment to the Treasurer, Jack Peterson, and includes contact information and mailing details.
